title: Exercising With Ankylosing Spondylitis

content: My relationship with exercise has been a difficult one since I got sick. There were times when I exercised regularly and was fully able to, but there have also been times when exercise felt impossible and my body just could not move.
Before I Was Diagnosed With AS

Ever since high school, I’ve been an active person. I enjoyed doing aerobic exercises, weights, and biking. I loved working out! It was an outlet for me. If I were upset or angry, I would work out. That was my thing.
Beforehand, I wasn’t exactly an active person, but I fully embraced it once I found that as my outlet. I was even doing Insanity Max 30 videos daily. I considered myself to be a fit person.
After Diagnosis

After I was diagnosed in 2018, I found that walking really helped with my pain. Initially, it was very hard and very painful, but once I started doing it daily for a few weeks, it started to feel less painful.

content_blocks.text: My relationship with exercise has been a difficult one since I got sick. There were times when I exercised regularly and was fully able to, but there have also been times when exercise felt impossible and my body just could not move.
Before I Was Diagnosed With AS

Ever since high school, I’ve been an active person. I enjoyed doing aerobic exercises, weights, and biking. I loved working out! It was an outlet for me. If I were upset or angry, I would work out. That was my thing.
Beforehand, I wasn’t exactly an active person, but I fully embraced it once I found that as my outlet. I was even doing Insanity Max 30 videos daily. I considered myself to be a fit person.
After Diagnosis

After I was diagnosed in 2018, I found that walking really helped with my pain. Initially, it was very hard and very painful, but once I started doing it daily for a few weeks, it started to feel less painful.

content: I found yoga a few months after being diagnosed. It felt like home. I was finally able to do a workout and feel good afterward! I was so happy to have found yoga. I did it daily for a long time. It was an exercise that I could do from the comfort of my own home, and I felt good after doing it. I felt accomplished and I could feel my body strengthening once again. It had been a good year since I was able to do a workout and feel good about it, so this was huge for me.
Back in 2018, my symptoms of pain and fatigue were a lot less severe than they are now. I also had fewer diagnoses (I now have fibromyalgia and microscopic colitis).
The Past Few Years

Ever since COVID-19 happened, my symptoms have been a little more severe than they were before. I deal with major chronic fatigue nowadays. My pain is somewhat manageable, but the fatigue is not. It makes life a lot more difficult.

content_blocks.text: I found yoga a few months after being diagnosed. It felt like home. I was finally able to do a workout and feel good afterward! I was so happy to have found yoga. I did it daily for a long time. It was an exercise that I could do from the comfort of my own home, and I felt good after doing it. The Past Few Years

Ever since COVID-19 happened, my symptoms have been a little more severe than they were before. I deal with major chronic fatigue nowadays. My pain is somewhat manageable, but the fatigue is not. It makes life a lot more difficult.

content: Because of my fatigue, it is harder for me to exercise. Most days my body feels extremely heavy, or I’m so tired that I just can’t stay awake.
Yoga and walking have almost disappeared from my life. It’s become so rare that I can actually do an exercise or a workout that it feels like a distant memory from when I could do these things.

When I feel OK enough to do an exercise, I sometimes try chair exercises. These are amazing and can really help with the fatigue afterward. They also make me feel accomplished, which is a rare feeling now, especially after exercising. I also sometimes try 1 to 2 kilometers on my exercise bike, but that’s on a really good day.
How I Feel

I know that exercise is important to living with ankylosing spondylitis, but -- and I’m sure you can relate -- some days exercise is simply not going to happen. I try my absolute best to exercise when I feel good enough, but those days are so few and far between.

content_blocks.text: Because of my fatigue, it is harder for me to exercise. Most days my body feels extremely heavy, or I’m so tired that I just can’t stay awake.
Yoga and walking have almost disappeared from my life. It’s become so rare that I can actually do an exercise or a workout that it feels like a distant memory from when I could do these things.

When I feel OK enough to do an exercise, I sometimes try chair exercises. These are amazing and can really help with the fatigue afterward. They also make me feel accomplished, which is a rare feeling now, especially after exercising. I also sometimes try 1 to 2 kilometers on my exercise bike, but that’s on a really good day.
How I Feel

I know that exercise is important to living with ankylosing spondylitis, but -- and I’m sure you can relate -- some days exercise is simply not going to happen. I try my absolute best to exercise when I feel good enough, but those days are so few and far between.

content: As exercise used to be my outlet, I don’t really have one anymore. I wish I did, but nothing feels as good as it did to do a hard workout. Sometimes I’ll try a calming video game, but that feels nothing like a good workout.

I will say, though, that when I was doing physiotherapy earlier in the year, it did help me to do more regular stretching and exercising. Once my 5 weeks were up and I wasn’t being held accountable anymore, I kind of fell out of it.
I know it takes a lot of self-discipline to get into a routine, and maybe that will be my New Year's resolution for 2024, but I also need to listen to my body and work around its needs.
Stay connected to others with ankylosing spondylitis. Join our Facebook Support Group now.
Photo Credit: Getty Images
